lines.text:
[to young Gordon]
See here, son. there's things a man of honor doesn't tell anyone, not even his father and mother.

[With irony]
It's a wise father who knows his own son, you know.

[to an agitated Nina]
Have you ever seen an insane person. Do you know what it means? I'm going to show you!

[Thinking to himself about telling Sam the truth]
I couldn't tell him. To kill happiness is a worse crime than taking a life.
In order for us fully to understand his characters, Eugene O'Neill allows them to express their thoughts aloud. As in life, these thoughts are quite different from the words that pass their lips.
This pleasant old town, doting. What memories it brings back.
[Inner thoughts]
Queer things, thoughts, our true selves. Spoken words are just a mask to disguise them.

[Inner thoughts]
Nina, here in my arms. How often I've dreamed of this. Dreams. That's the trouble. I'm only a dreamer. How she'd laugh if she could read my thoughts.

[Inner thoughts]
Oh, Gordon, lips on my lips, strong arms around me, spirit so brave and gay. Ashes. Ashes - dissolving into mud.

I gave him - what did I give him? Its what I didn't give. That last night, before he sailed, in his arms, knowing - something in me knowing that he would die. Never kiss me again, knowing so surely. And yet my cowardly brain lying, "No, he'll come back and marry you. You'll be happy ever after. With his children in your arms, looking up with his eyes. But, Gordon didn't marry me. And now Gordon is muddy ashes and I've lost my happiness forever.

[Inner thoughts]
How much need I tell him? I can't tell him the raw truth about her. I have to tone it down.
[Spoken]
Nina has been giving away more and more to a morbid longing for - martyrdom.
May I ask in what specific actions of hers this theory of yours is based?
On her evident craving to make an exhibition of necking, spooning, in general, with any patient in the institution who got a case on her.
[Inner thoughts]
Spooning - probably a mild word, but, strong enough for this ladylike soul.
You know what I'm inclined to suspect, Doctor? That you may be in love with Nina yourself.

[Inner thoughts]
Oh, really, I wonder if I am? Forget it! No woman's going to tangle up my career!
[Spoken]
No. In my mind she always belongs to Gordon. And I couldn't share a woman. Even with a ghost.
I can quite appreciate your feeling about Gordon. I wouldn't care to share with a ghost-lover myself. That species of dead is so invulnerably alive - even a Doctor couldn't kill one, eh?
Yes, he's gone. My father who began me. He's ended.
Life. You see, life is just one long drawn-out lie - with a sniffing sigh at the end.
Oh, Charlie. If you only knew how I'd want to run home to you - confess everything.
Confess what, Nina?
I've been bad, Charlie. Wicked. I need to be punished and you're the only one left to punish me.

Yes. It's all settled. You know, I feel so curiously calm. So at peace. You've done this Charlie. Without punishing me at all. You haven't punished me, you know. I don't feel as if you punished me hardly at all.

[Inner thoughts]
This is all my desire. I am this kind of lover. This is my love. My little girl, not woman.
Did she mind because Charlie Marsden drove us down here?
Of course not, why should she?
I don't know? I thought she was rather upset when he decided to stay overnight.
[Inner thoughts]
She acted so queerly. Seemed anxious to get me alone.
She's such a fussy old lady. She's probably afraid he'd criticize the bed sheets.
Ha-ha. He probably did!
It's a queer old house, Sam. It has voices. Old voices. I could hear them last night, Sam. Plainly. Tired whispers and high, meaningless laughter.

I've never been so happy in all my life. I tell you, marriage certainly puts the right kind of ambition into a fella. Unselfish ambition. You know, working for his wife and - perhaps, someone else, who knows?

[Inner thoughts]
Oh, here comes that fussbudget Marsden and me to see Nina. He's an old maid who seduces himself in his novels.

[Inner thoughts]
Queer fellow, Marsden. I thought he was so ingrown he didn't care about anyone. His mother. Now I begin to see him!

[to Ned]
Well, since you're out here professionally and my husband wants me to consult you, I might as well give you the whole case history. I warn you, it isn't pretty. But, I hope it will teach you not to be so cock-sure, in the future.

[Inner thoughts]
I love Ned. I've loved him ever since that afternoon, that scientific afternoon. What a goose I was. It twas then love came to me. I hid it from him. Held him to his aloof Doctor's pose and sent him away proud of his willpower. But, I've watched love grow in him until I'm sure. But, am I?

[Inner thoughts]
I love you. What do I care for anything in the world but you.

[Inner thoughts]
The touch of her skin. What do I care for anything else.

[Inner thoughts]
You do love me, Ned.

[Inner thoughts]
I don't love you.

[Inner thoughts]
Darrell and Nina. There's something unnatural here. Love and hate and lust! Where's Sam? Why isn't he here? I hate Nina! I must punish her!

[Inner thoughts - while cradling Sam's head in her chest]
Poor little boy. One gives birth to little boys. One doesn't drive them mad and kill them.
How 'bout the old scout?
Oh, he seemed fine, fellow. Yes, yes, he said he was having a gay time. When I saw him he was with a startling looking female. I gather he was quite involved.

[Inner thoughts]
How limp his hands. Is it possible, he loves me? How absurd.
[Spoken]
Alright, Charlie, dear, I'll forgive you.
You're the only genuinely modest person I know, Sam.
Who me? I'm the boob of the family. Except when it comes to business. I'll make the money, alright.
Hello, Marsden.
When did you get back from Europe?
This morning, on the Olympic.
[Inner thoughts]
Look out for this fellow. Always had it in for me. He's like a woman, smells out love.
You can't get me out of your blood anymore than I can get you out of mine.

[Inner thoughts]
I can't believe it. I'm growing older. In a few years, I'll have reached that state where a woman has finished living. Life passes her by.

He's sick of being babied, Nina. You don't realize he's getting to be a big boy now. We want him to grow up into a real he-man, not an old lady like Charlie. Now, that's what's the matter with Charlie, I'll bet. His mother never stopped babying him.
Perhaps you're right, Sam.
I know I'm right.
[Sam exits]

[Rolls her eyes]
Oh, heaven grant that I may someday tell this fool the truth!
Go ahead, dear. Row to victory! You can't lose.
We're always desiring death - for ourselves or others, aren't we?
You've got to give up owning people. Meddling in their lives as if you were God and had created them.
Miss Arnold, as a Doctor, I feel it my duty, that Mrs. Evans isn't herself. She's morbidly jealous of you and subject to queer delusions. So, get back to your race and God bless you.
Here, Madeline. Here is a rose for you. Here, your love. We who have died, salute you.

[Inner thoughts]
Queer creature. Something uncanny. Oh, what nonsense. Why, it's only poor old Charlie.
[Spoken]
Thank you, Uncle Charlie.
Oh, Ned, are you saying you wanted to tell Gordon something?
No. There's - nothing to tell.
You heard what Gordon said. He expects us to marry. But, he'll be so pleased when he knows you turned me down.
Yes. Our ghosts would torture us to death, wouldn't they.
We've saved a soul. Sam's soul. We brought him happiness. Surely that's not a lifetime lived in vain.
Fly up to heaven! Fly with your love, then. Fly always. Never crash to earth like my old Gordon. Be happy, dear! You've got to be happy!
I wonder if our old garden is the same? We'll pick flowers together, in the aging afternoons of Spring and Summer. I'm so contentedly weary of life.
